segments.text: So let's see if this works better than Mars Observer.
Okay, this is Ron Sharn interviewing Dale Cruikshank, older Colorado, October 19, 1993.
Dale, for the record, would you please give your full name?
Yes, I am Dale Paul Cruikshank.
And when and where were you born?
I was born in Des Moines, Iowa, 1939, August 10th.
When did you get interested in astronomy?
I got interested in astronomy when I was about 12 or 13 years old.
The first astronomical event of my life was the total eclipse of the sun of June 30, 1954, at which time I was 13 years old, I think.
And my mother took me and a school friend to northern Michigan to see the totality phase.
And it was a success.
And from then on, it was clear that I had to be an astronomer.
Where did you go to undergraduate school?
I was an undergraduate physics major at Iowa State University in Ames.
I graduated from there in 1961 and went from there then to the University of Arizona where I was a graduate student
I got a master's degree in planetary geology in 1966, I believe it was, and finished a PhD in 1968, also in the geology department with an emphasis on planetary geology.
So what were you doing at Yerkes in the summer of 1959?
When I was midway through my freshman year at Iowa State, I already started thinking about graduate school.
and began to write to various schools that had astronomy programs.
And one of those schools, of course, was the University of Chicago.
And I got a very nice letter back answering the questions I had asked and telling me about a summer program that was held at Yerkes Observatory for undergraduates and inviting me to apply for that.
I did apply and was told that the program was really for more advanced undergraduates than someone who was just finishing her freshman year.
but that if I could provide a suitable letter of recommendation, they would consider my application.
So this was correspondence with Joe Chamberlain, who at the time was the chairman of the student admission program, I think.

So I managed to get a letter of recommendation from Philip Riggs, who was the astronomer at the Drake University and operated the Drake Municipal Observatory, and with whom I'd become friends because I lived in Des Moines.
And so Riggs sent a letter of recommendation that was accepted by Chamberlain and the committee, and I was offered the summer job.
So I showed up at Yerkes in the early summer of 1958.
What did you do there?
The first summer, I worked in the darkroom on Kuiper's Lunar Atlas project, at which time
he was assembling the photographs from ground-based telescopes around the world, the best lunar photographs to assemble into the lunar atlas that was supported by the U.S. Air Force.
And I remember I'd had a lot of experience with darkroom work just as an amateur photographer, so it was pretty easy to fit into that role, and I enjoyed it a lot.
I remember the thrill on one afternoon when Kuiper came around to the
darkroom shortly after I had arrived and introduced himself and saw what I was doing and came in and was helping me produce a couple of prints from some of these lunar negatives.
And there we stood side by side with our hands in the developer tank rubbing on one of these prints to try to increase the development in a place that needed a little bit of extra help.
And it was a real thrill because I had known Kuiper's name, of course, from reading the textbooks and so on.
And there we were in the darkroom rubbing prints together.
We'll get back to him in a while, but now you got your PhD in what year?
Okay, where did you go from there?
I went pretty much directly to Moscow from there.
I had been interested in Russia, Russian language, Russian culture, the Russian science program since undergraduate days when I started to study the language.
And Kuiper was interested in it too.
He had
I, of course, spent my graduate years with him there in Tucson.
And he had developed contacts with the Soviet Union in terms of its lunar and planetary exploration program.
And I asked him to help me try to get one of the National Academy of Sciences exchange appointments to the Soviet Union.
The exchange program was fairly quiet but reasonably active at the time.
And he helped, and I got one of the appointments.
Um, shortly after I got my degree, uh, within a couple of months, I took off for Moscow, spent a better part of a year there and returned to Tucson in the summer of 1969.
What did you do aside from hearing me over the radio in the caucuses one time?
Yes.
What did you do at, in Moscow?
Um, the reason that it made sense to go there in the first place is that Vasily Moroz, uh, was a planetary astronomer.
working in the near infrared with equipment very comparable in quality to what Kuiper had in Tucson and the equipment that I had used under Kuiper's direction in Tucson.
So it made sense to go there and find out what Moroz was doing to work with him on planetary problems and so on.
He received me in Moscow, and we did, in fact, work together.
We observed together in the Crimea, wrote a couple of papers,
And it was, in general, quite an adventure.

So it was an opportunity to spend 10 or 11 months with the Russian counterpart of Kuiper's program to assess what they were doing, to actually make a few interesting observations, write a couple of papers.
Where'd you go from there?
I went back to Tucson in the summer of 69.
and spent almost, well, essentially a year there as Kuiper's associate.
It was clear, however, that I would always be cast in the role of a former student, and Kuiper and I had a couple of tussles over scientific issues during that year's time.
I was talking at the same time with the people in Hawaii, namely Bob Murphy,
who is now at NASA headquarters, David Morrison, and with Bill Sinton and John Jeffries at the University of Hawaii about a possible position there.
And they offered one.
I originally turned it down.
And then when things got tight with Kuiper again, it looked like it'd be appropriate to accept it.
I did.
And then in either late June or early July, I took off for Hawaii and stayed there for the better part of 18 years.
OK. What did you do at Hawaii?
Hawaii was, in the summer of 1970, putting the finishing touches on the 2.2-meter telescope that the NASA Planetary Program had funded.
NASA built the telescope roughly at a cost of $3 million.
The state of Hawaii provided the building and infrastructure roughly for a cost of $2 million.
This was one, of course, of the several NASA telescopes that were built during that era.
And they were trying to build a...
a program of ground-based astronomy, nighttime ground-based astronomy, because they already had a solar program.
And we're building staff.
We're finishing up this telescope and so on.
So it was an opportunity to get in on the ground floor of the exploitation and development of Mauna Kea as a ground-based observing site, which turned out, of course, later to be world-class quality.
So I went to Hawaii on a research position.
with no teaching obligations, and it was one of those very rare opportunities to move into an academic setting with all of the best of the opportunities and very little of the liabilities.
What did you work on?
I began working immediately on planetary problems.
The 2.2-meter telescope had a large Coudet spectrograph, which was available essentially as the telescope was commissioned.
And I began doing high dispersion coude spectroscopy, photographic spectroscopy.
And I remember the first problem I worked on was ammonia on Saturn.
There was not, at that time, a positive detection of ammonia on Saturn, although it was obvious on Jupiter.
Although it was in some textbooks, but it was wrong.
That's right, yes.
So I used, I think not the highest, but next highest dispersion spectrograph with about two angstroms per millimeter.
photographic looking for the 6450 band of ammonia on Saturn, and I couldn't find it with what I thought was a rather high sensitivity limit.
So I published an abstract and presented that at a DPS meeting, I think in 1971.
I believe, I'm not certain, but I believe that my abstract was the first published scientific result from the 88-inch or 2.2-meter telescope.
I've never made a point of that to my Hawaii colleagues, but for what it's worth, I think that is, in fact, true.
Where did you go after Hawaii?
Well, of course, Hawaii was an experience that ran nearly 18 years, and so I'd really developed almost all of my professional career during that period.
I left Hawaii...
After 17 and a half years.
In what year?
I believe late 87 and began a position at NASA Ames Research Center in California in January of 88.
Why the switch?
I made the switch primarily because my family and I were tired of living in Hawaii.
And it was, in fact, that personal decision that motivated us to consider leaving the islands.
Hawaii had tremendous professional opportunities and advantages.
And I was not in the slightest dissatisfied with those professional aspects of the situation.
The Institute for Astronomy during that 17 and a half years certainly did change.
But I was very much a part of it.
I was made to feel extremely welcome and valued there.
Yet, based on my family's personal desire to return to mainland United States, we decided to leave Hawaii.
And the opportunity for a position at NASA Ames arose largely through the help of Michael Werner,
and James Pollock at NASA Ames, both of whom wanted me there.
And so they made an opportunity, and we took it.
Are you still there?
I'm still at NASA Ames.
It's coming up on six years.
What are you doing, or what have you done?
I'm continuing the very kind of thing I was doing in Hawaii, specifically spectroscopy in the infrared and near-infrared of planetary objects.
And during the time since I started that business in the early 60s, which has now been
almost exactly 30 years.

Enormous advances have been made in the technology of infrared observations at all wavelengths and it's a real pleasure and a thrill to still ride on the crest of that wave as we continue to open up new levels of sensitivity and brightness and difficulty in looking at
the infrared spectral signatures of small, distant, faint, cold solar system bodies.
Isn't it nice not to have to ammoniate plates anymore?
It's nice not to have to ammoniate plates, and I did a fair amount of that, too.
I still got scars from some of that, but that's another story.
You're the obvious person to ask this.
While this project that I'm doing is subtitled NASA and the Rebirth of Planetary Astronomy,
I do want to mention some other stuff now.
The former Soviet Union had a huge program in science and everything, and a huge space program and so forth.

But as Gerard de Bacallure said, they'd take a telescope this small, holding his fingers a centimeter apart, and get an image this small, holding his fingers a millimeter apart, take an equation this long, holding his hands a yard apart,
And get a wrong result.
Now, it seems to me they had the highest ratio of effort to results that I've ever heard of in any field of science.
What's your view about that?
Is that true?
And if so, why?
Well, let me try to answer that with a specific focus on the near infrared, which is my primary area of expertise.
As I indicated before, I went to Moscow in the first place because Moroz had a detector and a spectrometer comparable to what Kuiper had.

And this involved a lead sulfide single element detector that was attached to a spectrometer working in the lead sulfide region, that is, lead sulfide cooled with dry ice or nitrogen and operating out to about two and a half or three microns.
Now, I'm told that the way the Russians got that lead sulfide detector is that in earlier years when the Russians were friends with the Chinese, that the Chinese had come upon
an American rocket with a heat-seeking guidance system.
And that heat-seeking, this was probably aftermath of the Korean conflict, maybe during the Korean conflict.
But anyway, the Chinese gave this rocket sensing device to the Russians, their friends.
The Russians took it apart, discovered that it was a lead sulfide detector, and proceeded to analyze it in such a way that they could make one themselves.
An entire institute of probably greater than 100 people was assigned this task.
And they, in fact, did make lead sulfide detectors of comparable quality.
A couple of these found their way into the hands of scientists, in particular.
And he was able to exploit it for scientific use.
As I'm told this story, this particular science institute was
this was essentially their only task, was to deal with this one detector system.
And after several years of working, continuing on it, they got so entrenched and ingrown and inbred that they even lost the technique themselves.
And after they had had this initial success, they couldn't do it anymore.
Yet the Institute and all the personnel stayed intact and proceeded down their merry way because apparently nobody called them off.
and told them to go do something else.
So that was apparently the apex, the culmination of Russian near-infrared detector development.
And to my understanding, it never got any better.
And they were never able, after that initial success, to keep up with Western achievements, Western developments in detector development.
Let's go back to GPK now.
He was on the Project Alsos mission, which everyone always confuses with Operation Paperclip, but Alsos went in with the combat troops sometimes ahead of them.
And that's where I understand that GPK picked up the infrared technology that he used.
Well, I think that's not entirely correct.
It's related.
Kuiper was working on Alsos to evaluate
German technological achievements and developments and so on.
And that story is very nicely told in David Dvorkin's book, by the way, the 1992 book.
Which is entitled?
I've forgotten.
It's something about the German vengeance weapon or something of the kind.
It's an excellent book and a very nice little piece, well referenced about Kuiper's involvement with Alsace.
In any case, Kuiper's academic colleague, Robert Cashman, in the United States, was the American developer of
of the lead sulfide detectors.

And Cashman worked with Kuiper or vice versa to produce one of these things after they were declassified, just following the war, to produce one of these things for use in an astronomical spectrometer at the McDonald Observatory.
What Kuiper learned about German detector development, I don't know in detail, but I think he found that they were
close on the heels or perhaps even a little bit better at these near-infrared detectors than the Americans were.
The details of that I'm not certain about.

But the upshot of it in terms of his ability to have a detector and begin this pioneering work in near-infrared spectroscopy, both in stellar and planetary work, came from his association with Cashman.
And Cashman's
A brief obituary of Cashman appeared not long ago in Physics Today, where there's a brief assessment of his work on these near-infrared detectors.
The association with Cashman, as I say, produced a detector, one of which, by the way, is now in the collection at the National Air and Space Museum.
I managed to salvage this from Kuiper's collection of memorabilia, and it was donated to the museum a couple of years ago.
So they have it, one of the very ones that was used in the original spectrometer that Kuiper used.
Now, Kuiper was, and I know this because I funded him when I was at headquarters, was the guy that first realized what a great site Mauna Kea was.
But he got frozen out of it.
What do you know about that?
The story of Kuiper's association with Mauna Kea is rather accurately told in the
two lengthy editorials by Mitch Waldrop in Science, and these appeared roughly 10 years ago.
I can't remember exactly.
It's a complex story.
Some of the details, I think, are forever obscure because they relate to Kuiper's feelings about it.
Essentially, Kuiper recognized the potential of Mauna Kea, dealt directly with the governor of the state of Hawaii, John Burns,
who received him very well and who supported the initial site surveys at Mauna Kea.

At the same time, however, the University of Hawaii was trying to build a program in astronomy, primarily in solar astronomy, as a follow-on to the International Geophysical Year, which had taken place in 1957-58.
There was work on aurora and, again, on the sun done on Haleakala,
And this work was done through the University of Hawaii.
Well, they hired a solar astronomer, John T. Jeffries, who brought with him an entourage of solar physicists from Boulder, Colorado.
And they began this program of solar work.
Well, they decided, while Kuiper was busily working with the governor of Hawaii to assess the qualities of Mauna Kea for nighttime astronomy, NASA solicited
proposals for a major optical telescope on Mauna Kea.
Kuiper, with the assistance of Harold Johnson, also in Tucson, naturally put in a proposal to do this.
But NASA didn't want a single proposal because it was clearly non-competitive.
So they solicited proposals from other agencies or other universities and were given proposals by Harvard University and also by the University of Hawaii.
John Jeffries, sort of on last minute, put together this proposal to go in in parallel with Kuiper's proposal to NASA for a telescope there.
After these proposals were evaluated, the choice was made to go with the University of Hawaii.
And William Brunk tells me, who was in the driver's seat at that time, that they at NASA headquarters felt that Kuiper was overextended.

He had too many irons in the fire at various places around the world, and they felt that John Jeffries and his solar crew, while more or less unproven for nighttime astronomy, should be given the opportunity to do it.
They were on the site, they were there, and should be given the opportunity, Kuiper being overextended.
The Harvard proposal, apparently, was not very competitive.
That was Menzel's.
That's right.
I'll tell you, since I'm writing a book, I can say anything I want.
Brunk was new.
He never did have any track record as a scientist.
Nancy Roman told me personally before I left headquarters that Kuiper would have a telescope on Mauna Kea over her dead body.
Nancy Roman's involvement is an element that I really don't know anything about.
Let me ask you something on a related matter.
Kuiper left
the directorship of Yerkes and McDonald rather suddenly.
And in fact, Frank Edmondson keeps telling me, although I've never seen any proof, that he says he's got documentary proof that Kuiper was summarily fired as director of Yerkes and McDonald.
What do you know about that?
I would have to refer to my notes on that.
I've been in touch with Frank Edmondson about this and with various other people as well.

As I was putting together the manuscript for my biographical memoir on Kuiper that will soon be published by the National Academy, I was fully convinced that this assertion is true and that Kuiper was forced to step down.
And I would have to refer to my notes and sources to recall the exact circumstances.
on that, and I have agreed already to provide that to you, Ron, so that you can consider that.
You're on the record now.
Sure.
Fair enough.
Let me ask you a personal question.
Because G.P.K.
obviously is a key player in the rebirth of planetary astronomy, and I can't interview him.
What was he like?
Kuiper was a very intense personality, a very imposing figure physically,
and an absolutely domineering character intellectually.
He had a profound effect on my life, certainly at the professional level, but as the years go by, I see he had a profound effect on my life in a personal sense, too.
There are other people upon whose lives he has had similar profound influences, and Tom Geralds is one such.
Tom Geralds and I have, over the last many years,
talked a lot, written a lot to one another, trying to come to grips, to reach peace with this effect that Kuyper has had on both of our lives.
Gerholtz, of course, is a fellow Dutchman.
In any case, and dealt with Kuyper primarily earlier on, in any event, Kuyper was a domineering individual whose intellect one could only respect and
One evidence of that is that even essentially everyone who worked with him called him Dr. Kuiper.
He was Gerard only to a very, very small inner circle of people who were essentially his contemporaries.
Fred Whipple.
Fred Whipple and Harold Johnson and Frank Lowe and those folks were able to call him Gerard, which, by the way, wasn't his real name.
That's an Americanized version of Garrett.
which was his Dutch given name.
In any case, he, on the one hand, was a marvelous conversationalist, had a very nice sense of humor, and was a joy to be around in many respects.
He was extremely impatient, on the other hand, with anybody who appeared to be intellectually inferior to him.
to have less knowledge than him and so on, he didn't deal with students very well.
He was very difficult to work with and to work for.
His general demeanor was one of extreme arrogance, and it took a lot to get past that, to be able to work with him, to be able to stand him.
But once you did,
there was a lot to be derived from the association, a lot of positive things to be derived from the association.
And for those of us who were able to get on top of that demeanor issue, we derived a lot of benefit from the association.
Joe Chamberlain said something about the Quake.
He said he was a very loyal man.
And I mentioned that to Fred Whipple.
And he agreed.
He said, yes, he certainly was perhaps too loyal in some cases.
But he said Gerard's main problem was he couldn't get along with people.
That's right.
That's quite right.
And I think that that showed up when Kuiper arrived in America around 1929 or 1930 and went to the Lick Observatory as a postdoc, later to become a Kellogg Fellow at the Lick Observatory.
I mentioned earlier Philip Riggs, who was the astronomer in Des Moines where I grew up.
Philip Riggs was a graduate student at Lick Observatory when Kuyper arrived as a fresh postdoc from Holland.

When I told, after I spent the first summer at Yerkes Observatory, these now in 1958, and went back to Des Moines and talked to Philip Riggs, who had recommended me for the job, the first thing he asked me was, has old Gerard Kuyper learned to get along with anybody yet?
And that told me right then and there that this problem had arisen
And this element of Kuiper's personality showed up from day one.
By the way, Phil Riggs spent a summer at the University of Illinois.
I was his teaching assistant.
Oh, is that right?
That's great.
He's a wonderful man.
Now, let me connect Kuiper with going back now to the history of planetary astronomy.
When you started, did you feel inferior to real astronomers who worked on stars and galaxies?
Well, in a way, yes, and in a way, no.
As I've already mentioned, I got my first acquaintance with real professional astronomers at Yerkes Observatory.
And this was an extraordinary opportunity for a boy from the cornfields of Iowa to go to this imposing architectural structure
in the farmland of Wisconsin, a place from the last century with gargoyles and all that sort of thing.
It was neogothic right there in the middle of Wisconsin.
The first foreigners I ever talked to, the first people with advanced degrees, essentially, that I ever spoke with were there at Yerkes.
So this summer of 1958 was an extraordinary experience.
Well, I say that to answer your question that
Naturally, Yerkes Observatory was populated and dominated by classical stellar astronomers, the likes of Morgan, Hiltner, Abt, Chandrasekhar.
S. Chandrasekhar.
S. Chandrasekhar, and on and on.

And Kuiper and his entourage of flunkies, essentially, some transports or transplants from England, amateur astronomers from England, and here this kid down in the darkroom rubbing prints with the great man himself.
So Kuiper was an anomaly.
His program was an anomaly.
And all of us who were part of it were made to feel anomalous.
We were, sure, treated well.
I was given opportunity to spend evenings playing with a 40-inch telescope and so on.
Yet there was this element of the whole thing was an amateur astronomy project.
Do you think the fact that Kuiper was able to get big bucks out of the Air Force rankled with some of the?
Oh, I think it must have, sure.

The thing that I have to keep reminding myself is that when I got acquainted with Kuiper in that summer of 1958, the man had already done an entire career's worth of classical stellar astronomy, double star work, white dwarf work, and stellar spectroscopy, and done excellent work, the bolometric corrections and so on, some of which is still very valuable work.
He had begun to pursue solar system work as essentially an outgrowth of his interest in binary stars and their formation and so on.
But the man already had this strong scientific reputation before he even began to pursue planetary things.
And as I've pointed out in my biographical memoir, his discovery of the atmosphere of Titan was purely an accident.
He ran out of white dwarfs to take spectra of during the night at McDonald's
And he decided to look at a few planetary objects, discovered methane on Titan, and that was a sort of beginning of his observational work in planetary astronomy.
Well, anyway, that was an accident.
But he was the director of Yerkes, the director of this bunch of stellar classical astrophysics prima donnas, who by this time had, I think, grown to loathe him.
Yet they had to deal with him because he was the director, and he also commanded this very large amount of funding.
from an unexpected source.
It was from a government source, and astronomers weren't used to that in those days, and they had no choice but to deal with him, this person with a richness of resources.
So I think there was a resentment there that grew out of the jealousy over the funding.
It grew out of the
the difficulty of his personality.
When Otto Struve was the director, Otto was able to keep these prima donnas pretty much in harmony, just because of the strength of his own personality and his own managerial skills.
But when Struve was gone, the place began to unravel.
And it unraveled along a variety of lines that were related to these strong personalities, the diversity of scientific interests, and no doubt the jealousy over research funds.
In your personal opinion, back around 1958, 59, 60, do you think that planetary astronomy was considered second rate and inferior by the, quote, establishment?
Oh, it's clear to me that it was, yes.
As I say, my first connections with the establishment were at this rather peculiar place, Yerkes Observatory.

But as I expanded my experiences and contacts to various other places in the country and other institutions, it became clearer and clearer that planetary science, planetary astronomy, as it was considered in those days, that's really all there was, was definitely regarded as inferior.
And I've spent the last 30 years in some ways trying to understand how that came to be.
And is there any way to, is there any antidote for it?
Or are we always going to be plagued with this problem as long as planetary science is identified as such?
That brings up the next question.
How do you think real, quote unquote, astronomers think of planetary astronomy now?
Now.

I believe that the generation represented by Kuiper, and this includes such people as Jeff Burbage, who was a personal enemy of Kuiper, and various other people of that generation still have rather negative feelings about it.
Let's say the people at what's now Mount Palomar Observatory, these folks are cosmologists primarily.
and classical astronomers.
And I'm sure they have a very dim view of the value of planetary science.
The Mount Wilson syndrome.
Yeah, right.
But even in Hawaii, where we had a rather unusual situation.
As I say, the program was just getting started in 1970.
That is, the nighttime astronomy program was just getting started.
And planetary people were already involved.
Bill Sinton was there, David Morrison, Bob Murphy, and then I showed up in 1970.
And because I know I wrote the funding memo, that funds were given to Hawaii, committed for a long time, that they must do planetary work.
That's right.
They must do planetary work.
And that was all fine.
I mean, that's why the telescope was built, but it was clear that it would be used for
A large fraction of the time would be for planetary work and the remainder for classical astronomy.
The point I'd like to make is that that program developed and grew with a complete intertwining of classical astronomers, stellar astronomers, and planetary people.
And the outcome of that was very positive in that there was a mutual respect, a family atmosphere and attitude,
such that we all took a lot of pleasure in each other's successes and discoveries.

And people interested in galaxies, such as Alan Stockton, people interested in classical stellar spectroscopy, such as Sidney Wolfe and Walter Bonsack, were working side by side with those people I've already mentioned doing planetary work.
And as we grew up together, all of us having gone there, except Bill Sinton as fairly young people,
we developed camaraderie and a family mood, which was very productive and very supportive.
Before I left Hawaii, that had begun to change because John Jeffries had left, Don Hall had become the director, and his hiring policies
had put into faculty positions there a larger number of cosmologists and people interested in extragalactic studies.
And so the attitude toward planetary science, I think, even in Hawaii, had begun to shift a bit, to become a little less tolerant, a little less interested, and maybe a little less respectful.
However, while I was still there, planetary astronomy had,
still an important role at the Institute, primarily because of the funding structure.

Also, we had, you know, productive scientists, but there was still sort of a cudgel that we held in that the 88-inch telescope was still supported primarily by a grant from NASA Planetary Programs, and in the form of a large single grant that exceeded a quarter of a million dollars for a combination of support of the telescope,
and the support of the planetary research, all of which was under the single umbrella of one grant.
And that structure broke down essentially as I left by mutual agreement with headquarters and the Institute for Astronomy.
But at least during the years I was there, planetary astronomy was respected.
It was well supported.
And we had a wonderful supportive arrangement with the classical stellar astronomers.
I think that is less so now.
That was one case where people actually talked to each other.
That's right, and in friendly terms.
One last thing about Kuiper.
Do you think the fact that he was in what was considered a second rate field reinforced his personality character, his negative personality characters, and gave him this embattled status?
I'm not so sure.

I think Kriper was a difficult personality to the core, and that he had an element of arrogance and self-assurance that allowed him to rise above or beyond the criticisms of his colleagues and pursue his own path with complete self-assurance.
At the time, he had a good relationship with S. Chandrasekhar,
I think they also had some difficult times, but they were in very different areas of science.
And I think that, well, I'm not sure where I was going with that, but I'll just say again that I think Kuiper didn't have a siege mentality.
He felt completely self-assured that his course was right.
Now we'll get on to a different subject, and this is something that I'm
Nothing has been written about this.
And the people involved are all dead.
So I've got to ask people's personal opinions who are in the field now.
At the turn of the century, planetary astronomy was still a popular topic.
I mean, Henry Norris Russell did stuff on Venus and all that.
By 1920, it was not only not popular, it wasn't safe to be in what killed planetary astronomy.
I think two people killed it.
I think Percival Lowell killed it in the United States, and Camille Flammarion killed it in Europe.
That's exactly Gerard de Vaucouleur's comment.
Well, I haven't talked to de Vaucouleur about this, but I...
It's right in this book.
Good, great.
I came to this awareness when I was researching some work by Barnard, Edward Emerson Barnard, on his life and times.
Barnard was a voice of reason during the Canals on Mars era.

He was a Chautauqua series lecturer with lantern slides of pictures that he had taken, being one of the great pioneers of photography and astronomy and discoverer of comets and whatnot, and the fifth satellite of Jupiter.
He was a well-known personality, but he didn't write popular books and didn't have the same charisma, contacts, and persona that Percival Lowell did.

Percival Lowell wrote numerous books on the habitability of Mars and the nature of Mars' intelligent civilization and all this and that, based in large part upon his observations and those of his colleagues under his thumb at Lowell Observatory of the canals and seasonal changes on Mars.
This attracted a lot of attention in the popular press and lent an aura of
of silliness to planetary studies as seen by classical astronomers.
What you indicated was true, that a major part of the program of nearly all professional astronomical observatories in the latter part of the 19th century was planetary work.
They were doing planetary visual observations, searches for satellites,
spectroscopy and photography, what have you.
And this was a very legitimate part of classical astronomy at the end of the 19th century.
Well, this business about the canals on Mars, I think, gave that an aura of science fiction and that primarily the efforts and the charisma of Percival Lowell in this country did it.
I believe, although I'm not as well acquainted with it,
that parallel activity in Europe by Flammarion with, again, a volley of popular books and articles produced essentially the same effect there.
What's the best piece of work you've done in astronomy?
The best piece of work I've done is probably the work on the spectrum of Neptune's satellite, Triton, in which persistence in

Studying the near-infrared spectrum produced the detection and identification of methane, frozen methane on Triton, and frozen nitrogen, which we now recognize as the dominant material on the surface of Triton and Pluto.
I continue to pursue this as the technology permits us to do a better and better job.
Now, in 1989, of course, Voyager flew by Triton and found some very interesting things and corroborated the presence of nitrogen and methane, but it didn't show anything else.

And in the meantime, we've found from additional ground-based work, carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide ices on Triton, and evidence of some other very interesting hydrocarbons, which we haven't even yet announced.
So it turns out that the persistence in trying to

detect, measure, and interpret the spectrum of a little object, 30 astronomical units from the sun, something that has a temperature in the neighborhood of less than 40 Kelvin and is to the telescope only almost 14th magnitude, has proven to be a very, very rich spectrum, which we continue to interpret and find extremely interesting chemistry and information on the early development of the solar system.
What did you have the most fun doing so far?
Well, certainly the work on nitrogen has been some of the most fun.
I also had an enormous amount of fun with our 20-micron detections of faint objects in the solar system.
And I remember very well standing on the Cassegrain platform in the cold at the 88-inch telescope in Hawaii in the mid-'70s, measuring the thermal radiation from Trojan asteroids
at 20 microns.
These are objects which had never been detected thermally before.
And I was able to get the first measurements of heat from those dark, small, little objects.
And by the way, the detection of heat itself indicated that they were dark objects which absorbed a lot of sunlight and had low albedos.
Similarly, with two of the outer satellites of Jupiter, I knew what I was looking for.
I knew that if I could detect them at all, that that meant they were little black objects.
And standing there on the platform seeing the strip chart recorder make a positive detection was a tremendous thrill.
Have you had any fiascos or dead ends?
Oh, sure.
I've had some mistakes.
What's your greatest fiasco?
Well, I'd preface this by saying that I've enjoyed being on what is a cutting edge.
of detections and measurements in planetary astronomy.
And when you're on an edge, you can fall sometimes on one side and fall sometimes on the other.
I've already told you about the successes in which I fell on the right side of the edge.
There have been a couple of failures where I've fallen on the other side.
Probably the worst one was the apparent detection of helium emission in the spectrum of Io, Jupiter's satellite Io.
We in Hawaii, one of the first things I did there was to work on a near-infrared Fourier transform spectrometer.

And one of the first things we looked at with this spectrometer after we finally got it online with the 88-inch telescope was IO, by which time sodium emission had already been detected in the spectrum by Robert Brown and colleagues.
But we looked at it, and we detected this.
We, that is with Carl Pilcher and Bill Sinton, we detected helium emission, the 10-8-30 band or line of helium.
We rushed to a meeting that was held in Ithaca and reported this and sent out an IAU circular on it.
And Don Hunton congratulated us on the detection of helium emission.
No one understood what it meant, but they were all willing to believe that this very peculiar object had helium emission.
And we all set out to understand it.
And then we discovered that this was spurious because the interferometer control system used a helium lamp.
to provide the clocking frequency.
And while we could not imagine how this Spiria signal got into the signal chain, indeed it did.
And our detection of helium on Io was wrong.
And Larry Trafton continues to remind me of that, even though the rest of the world until this very moment has forgotten, mercifully forgotten.
If you read
any of the popular books about exploration of the solar system that have been coming out in the last 20 years.
It's all done by the space probes.
Of course.
What's your opinion?
My opinion is that the space probes wouldn't have even known where to go or what to look at or how to look at it if it hadn't been for the work that has been done on the ground.
And certainly the incremental improvement in our understanding of the planets was enormously augmented by the space probes.
space probes.
But I'd remind you again just what I said.
When Voyager got to Triton, it detected nitrogen and methane, but it sure didn't see the carbon monoxide or the carbon dioxide.
